channel.title: NTFS in Debian + Xorg.conf
channel.description:
I have two problems.. I recently installed Debian Etch.
Anyway, I'm trying to access files in my Windows Partition, and I'm having problems.. So I installed FUSE and NTFS-3G, I mounted my NTFS partition to /media/sda1. No problems so far..
Now, I go to access /media/sda1, "You don't not have the privileges to view this blah blah", so I go into terminal.
su chown -R myusername /media/sda1
So now I can access /media/sda1 and all it's folders.. However, all the files have red x's in the corner, and some files have locks in another corner.
Next I go into Nautilus using Root Terminal, and see if I can get anything to work.. Now, in Root Nautilus, everything works.. Except, if I click on the Properties > Permissions and try to change anything it says something like it can't change the permissions of blah blah file.
Edit: I forgot to mention, in my normal User, whenever I try to run a file, it says "unable to run, file could not be found" and in Root, it runs perfectly.
So, it works fine in root, just not in my normal user.. And I'd rather not have to use Root every time I want to access one file. So does anyone know anything that can help?

item.title: NTFS in Debian + Xorg.conf
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Pretty sure FUSE and ntfs-3g are two different drivers, so installing both can do nothing but cause problems. ntfs-3g is the way to go, remove fuse.

As for setting up dual monitors, you are asking for heartache editing xorg.conf yourself, especially when nvidia provides a handy tool with its driver to do ALL of the work for you. It should be in kmenu>system>nvidia settings if you are using KDE, otherwise run ‘/usr/bin/nvidia-settings’, then it is literally a click and point operation, if you need more help when you get there for some reason ask.

It looks like you installed the nvidia drivers and therefore have ‘nvidia-settings’, but if not download a program called Envy to do it for you.

Read full topic

@sppt wrote:

do you perhaps have a SLI card?
if you don’t, you’ll have to remove

Section "Device" Identifier "nVidia Corporation G70 [GeForce 7300 GT]2" Driver "nvidia" BusID "PCI:1:0:0" Option "UseFBDev" "true" Screen "1" EndSection

and then change

Device		"nVidia Corporation G70 [GeForce 7300 GT]2"

into

Device		"nVidia Corporation G70 [GeForce 7300 GT]"

i’m not sure if it’ll work, but i think it will
